Graphical abstract The 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst was prepared by loading Re on top of the CuZnZr catalyst. The addition of Re improved active metal dispersion, allowing ZnO to perform its spacer function fully and reducing the size and number of Cu species aggregations. In the meantime, Re enhanced the conversion of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation intermediate γ-butyrolactone to 1,4-butanediol. Re significantly improved the catalyst performance, achieving an 85 % yield of 1,4-butanediol at 190 °C and 6 MPa. Producing 1,4-butanediol with selective hydrogenation of maleic anhydride has significant financial benefits. This work reported a “green” one-step method for preparing 1,4-butanediol from maleic anhydride in a gas-phase fixed bed continuous flow reactor over an efficient 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst for the first time. In this paper, CuZnZr composite metal oxides were synthesized using the co-precipitation technique, followed by impregnation of Re to produce xRe/CuZnZr catalysts. The study aimed to investigate the effects of including Re on the catalyst's structure and performance. The results obtained from the characterization indicate that the presence of Re in the system restricts the growth of Cu0 grains. In addition, the inclusion of Re facilitated the utilization of ZnO as an effective spacer, reducing the size and quantity of Cu species agglomerates and enhancing active metal dispersion. This phenomenon may be attributed to being the primary factor responsible for the observed enhancement in the activity of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation reaction. Meanwhile, Re facilitated the transformation of γ-butyrolactone, an intermediate resulting from the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride into 1,4-butanediol. The 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst exhibited favorable catalytic activity under the conditions of 190 °C and 6 MPa, resulting in the complete conversion of maleic anhydride and a selectivity of 85 % towards 1,4-butanediol. The catalyst showed consistent catalytic performance throughout the 200 h. The finding about the impact of Re promoter on Cu-based catalysts has the potential to yield a highly efficient catalytic system for alcohol generation. Keywords Maleic anhydride Hydrogenation 1,4-Butanediol Copper-based catalyst Rhenium promoter Fixed bed reactor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a critical C4 compound, maleic anhydride is mainly produced by oxidizing n-butane [1–3] or the biomass platform compound 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [4–7]. Maleic anhydride has been produced in excess with the technological breakthrough and large-scale industrial production of maleic anhydride from n-butane oxidation [8]. Therefore, there has been much study in the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride and its derivatives to produce γ-butyrolactone (GBL), 1,4-butanediol (BDO), and tetrahydrofuran (THF). Among these is 1,4-butanediol, employed as an organic chemical intermediate in medicine, agriculture, and the chemical industry, as well as a solvent, plasticizer, polyalcohol fuel cell, etc. [9–11]. In recent years, the biodegradable plastics field has developed rapidly with the introduction of the global “plastic restriction” and “plastic ban” policies. The demand for polyurethane (PU), polybutylene succinate (PBS), polybutylene terephthalate (PBT), etc. [12–14] have surged. At the same time, the demand for 1,4-butanediol as a synthetic monomer for these products is also increasing. The reported literatures were always focused on the liquid-phase hydrogenation to produce 1,4-butanediol from maleic anhydride derivatives like butanedioic acid and γ-butyrolactone. Le et al. [15] examined the utilization of Cu-Pd/HAP bimetallic catalysts in the liquid-phase hydrogenation process of butanedioic acid intending to produce 1,4-butanediol. The Pd component facilitated the generation of butanol as well as increased the catalytic activity, while Cu promoted the generation of 1,4-butanediol. The selectivity of the catalysts for the complete conversion of butanedioic acid reached 82 %, and Cu-Pd alloying boosted the catalytic activity. Xu et al. [16] studied Cu/Al2O3 and CuLa x /Al2O3 catalysts for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of γ-butyrolactone to 1,4-butanediol. The inclusion of LaO x species was found to enhance the creation of active sites at the interface between Cu+ and LaO x . This appearance facilitated the rapid adsorption and activation of γ-butyrolactone. At 200 °C and 4 MPa hydrogen pressure, the ultimate 1,4-butanediol yield could be over 90 % because of enhanced catalyst stability. The synthesis of 1,4-butanediol in industrial production typically involves a two-step reaction process utilizing maleic anhydride. One method involved the esterification of maleic anhydride to produce dialkyl maleate as the first process. After that, 1,4-butanediol was obtained through the gas-phase hydrogenation of dialkyl maleate [17]. Chen et al. [18] prepared Cu/SBA-15 catalysts by different methods to investigate their efficacy in hydrogenating dimethyl maleate to 1,4-butanediol. The characterization results that the specific surface area of metallic copper influenced the hydrogenolysis activity of the catalysts. The homogeneous deposition precipitation approach exhibited the highest catalytic performance among the different methods used. The 1,4-butanediol yield after passing through the fixed-bed reaction was 66.1 % at 220 °C and 5 MPa. Another process used in the industry involved the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride at high temperatures and low pressure to ensure a high yield of γ-butyrolactone. The product of the first step was then further hydrogenated at low temperatures and high pressure to prepare 1,4-butanediol. Nevertheless, there has been limited research conducted on the one-step gas-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to produce 1,4-butanediol. The primary component that restricts the process is constrained by thermodynamic considerations [19]. It has been observed that a decrease in reaction temperature is directly proportional to an increase in the selectivity of 1,4-butanediol [20–22]. However, the reduction in reaction temperature resulted in a corresponding decrease in catalyst activity, resulting in suboptimal yield and stability. To make 1,4-butanediol in one step by hydrogenating maleic anhydride in the gas phase, the key is to make high-efficiency multiphase catalysts that work at lower temperatures. This study modified copper-based catalysts with rhenium to increase their activity, selectivity, and stability. Metal Re has a broader range of uses in CO bond hydrogenation because it is better at resisting acid for organic dicarboxylic acids and has high stability as a catalyst. Di et al. [23] conducted the synthesis of loaded Re-Ru catalysts through microwave pyrolysis to hydrogenate butanedioic acid to 1,4-butanediol. A selectivity of 70.1 % was reported at complete conversion, and it was observed that the existence of Re-Ru bimetallic interaction had an essential influence on enhancing the production of 1,4-butanediol and improving the saturation of hydrogenation intermediates on the catalyst's surface. Tapin et al. [24] focused on examining the efficacy of Re-Pd/TiO2 catalysts in facilitating the hydrogenation process of butanedioic acid to produce 1,4-butanediol. The reduced state catalysts exhibit the Re3 p and Re0 species' coexistence, as demonstrated by using characterization methods such as XANES and EXAF. The Re0 species effectively promoted the transformation of butanedioic acid to γ-butyrolactone, while the Re3+ oxidized near Pd0 promoted the further transformation of γ-butyrolactone to 1,4-butanediol. Therefore, the introduction of Re and the interaction between Re-Ru and Re-Pd effectively promoted the hydrogenation of butanedioic acid. This study involved the synthesis of a series of CuZnZr composite metal oxides using the co-precipitation method. Subsequently, these metal oxides were loaded with Re by the impregnation method, resulting in the formation of xRe/CuZnZr catalysts. The catalytic performances of the catalysts were thoroughly assessed in the production of 1,4-butanediol using a one-step gas-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride. The catalysts exhibited a notable enhancement in their catalytic performance by the manipulation of the Re loading quantity. Furthermore, a comprehensive analysis was conducted to comprehensively evaluate the physicochemical features of the catalysts, including factors such as metal dispersion, structural properties, basicity, and surface electronic states. The findings indicated that the catalysts 2Re/CuZnZr exhibited appropriate Cu0 particle size and a high level of active metal dispersion. The catalysts comprising 2Re/CuZnZr exhibited remarkable selectivity towards the production of 1,4-butanediol, together with favorable catalytic performance and stability during the process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Maleic anhydride (99.5 %), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (99.9 %), ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O (99.5 %), Cu(NO3)23H2O (99.9 %), Re2O7 (99.99 %), Na2CO3 (99.5 %), Acetone (99.5 %)sourced from Beijing InnoChem Science & Technology Co. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The CuZnZr catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation employing a 1.0 mol/L Na2CO3 aqueous solution as the precipitating agent. A weighed 42.3 g of Cu(NO3)23H2O, 42 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and 15.4 g of ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O was introduced into a 1 L volume of deionized water to make a composite solution. The composite solution and precipitant were added dropwise into a beaker at the same time under the heating of a water bath at 60 °C, and the flow rate of the two substances was modified to ensure that the pH remained 7. The temperature of the water bath was raised to 80 °C after dropwise addition, and aging was performed for 5 h. The catalyst precursor was subjected to cooling at ambient temperature and thereafter underwent a further aging process lasting for 12 h. Then, deionized water was used to wash the sample numerous times until the filtrate pH reached 7.0. The precipitate was first dried for 12 h at 120 °C before being eventually roasted for 4 h at 500 °C in a muffle furnace. The catalyst after roasting that was prepared underwent compression and fragmentation to form particles ranging in size from 20 to 40 mesh. These catalysts were subsequently designated as CuZnZr. CuZn catalyst, CuZr catalyst and ZnZr catalyst were prepared using the same method. The difference was that the CuZn catalyst was prepared using a mixed aqueous solution of 21.2 g of Cu(NO3)23H2O and 21 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, the CuZr catalyst was prepared using a mixed aqueous solution of 21.2 g of Cu(NO3)23H2O and 20.5 g of ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O, and the ZnZr catalyst was prepared using a mixed aqueous solution of 21 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and 7.7 g of ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O. Weigh x was 0.04 g, 0.16 g, 0.32 g and 0.64 g of Re2O7 dissolved in 12 g of acetone. The samples were then added to 12 g of catalyst CuZnZr, respectively, and the samples were macerated at room temperature for 48 h. The samples were then dried at 100 °C for 6 h and finally at 150 °C for a further 24 h. The produced catalyst was given the designation xRe/CuZnZr (x was 0.25,1,2 and 4 respectively). The 2Re/CuZn catalyst, the 2Re/CuZr catalyst and the 2Re/ZnZr catalysts were all loaded with Re using the same method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Supporting Information is a list of all the characterization methods employed in this study. 2.4 Gas-phase hydrogenation test In a fixed-bed stainless steel tubular reactor with an inner diameter of 10 mm and a length of 700 mm, maleic anhydride was gas-phase hydrogenated to yield 1,4-butanediol. The thermostatic portion of the reactor was loaded with 6.4 mL of 20–40 mesh catalyst, and quartz sand was added to both ends. A backpressure valve was used to keep the hydrogen pressure at 6.0 MPa, and the Brooks 5850E Gas Mass Flow Controller controlled the hydrogen flow. The catalyst was reduced in situ for 3 h at 280 °C under an H2 flow rate of 1100 mL/min. After cooling the catalyst bed to the reaction temperature, the raw material maleic anhydride dissolved in methanol to form a uniform solution was introduced to a vaporizer by a metering pump before entering the reactor. After going through a high-fractionation tank, the products were collected in a conical flask and subjected to gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 6890 N) analysis using a capillary column (HP-Wax) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The following formulae were used to compute the product selectivity and maleic anhydride conversion: Conversion % = mol of MA charged - m o l o f M A l e f t mol of MA charged S e l e c t i v i t y % = mol of product × C a t o m s i n p r o d u c t m o l o f M A c h a r g e d - m o l o f M A l e f t × C a t o m s i n s u b s t r a t e × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of catalysts The N2 physisorption results of the catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms are shown in Fig. 1 . All the catalysts exhibit typical Langmuir-type IV isotherms with H1-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures in all the samples. By comparing CuZn and CuZnZr catalysts, it was found that adding Zr increased the BET-specific surface. The pore diameter and pore volume decreased with the increase in Re loading, which might be caused by the blockage of the pore channels by a small amount of Re during the impregnation process. The metallic Cu surface area and dispersion in CuZnZr, 2Re/CuZnZr, and 4Re/CuZnZr catalysts were evaluated by N2O titration (Table 2 ). The inclusion of Re demonstrated a notable impact on the Cu-specific surface area. It has been attributed to the loaded Re covering part of the surface copper metal during catalyst preparation, reducing the amount of surface copper metal. As a result, the catalyst's metallic Cu dispersion and metal-specific surface area were lowered. 3.2 Structural and morphological characteristics The XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced xRe/CuZnZr catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 , respectively. Fig. 2(a) shows a series of diffraction peaks for CuO and ZnO, indicating that two typical well-crystallized phases of CuO and ZnO were synthesized in the samples. Peaks below 30° in the image are Carbon (PDF#18-0311). This characteristic peak is present in both 2Re/CuZnZr and 4Re/CuZnZr, but not in CuZnZr. Therefore, this characteristic peak is due to the residual trace carbon after drying with acetone as a solvent when loaded with metal Re. The grain sizes of CuO and ZnO for the three groups of catalysts were summarised (Table 2) and the results showed that the CuO grain size was basically unchanged, and the ZnO grain size slightly decreased with the increase of Re loading. Fig. 2(b) shows the XRD patterns of the reduced state of CuZnZr with different loadings of Re. The peaks below 30° for the reduced state 4Re/CuZnZr catalyst correspond to SiO2 (PDF#82-1570), which is due to the fact that the catalyst was in-situ reduced in the reactor using quartz sand to fill in the ends, and a small amount of quartz sand was left behind during the transfer of the catalyst. The peak at 2θ = 30.3° for CuZnZr corresponds to ZrO2 (PDF#50-1089), and the comparison reveals that the peak disappears after loading Re because the presence of Re promotes ZrO2 to show a highly dispersed state. The peaks at 2θ = 43.2°, 47.8°, 50.6°, and 57.7° correspond to Cu0 (PDF#70-3039), which is the active center for the generation of 1,4-butanediol by gas-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride [25]. The crystal size of Cu0 was calculated using the Scherrer formula. The results (Table 2) showed that the crystal size of Cu0 decreased continuously with the increase of Re loading, and the Re limited the growth of Cu crystals. The peaks at 2θ = 32.5°, 35.0°, and 37° correspond to ZnO, and the state of ZnO did not change before and after reduction. In addition, Fig. 2(b) showed that the intensity of the ZnO and Cu diffraction peaks was significantly weakened, the peak range was broadened and the crystallinity was reduced. This may be because the addition of Re reduced the grain size of ZnO after reduction (Table 2), which induced a decrease in the crystallinity of ZnO [26]. Another reason may be that the presence of Re strengthened the metal-carrier interaction (SMSI) of Cu and ZnO [27]. The morphology and distribution of metal particles were studied by TEM and STEM-EDS images. 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst led to good catalytic performance in the later evaluation (Fig. 9 and Table S2) of one-step gas-phase hydrogenation. Fig. 3 shows TEM pictures of CuZnZr and 2Re/CuZnZr catalysts in their reduced states. The formation of metal oxide crystals during the synthesis of catalysts using the co-precipitation method is affected by the interaction of different species, so all samples show different particle sizes and irregular agglomerates, which is a common phenomenon [28]. ZrO2 was not found in the images, probably due to its high dispersion and low crystallinity [29]. Regularly shaped particles and agglomerates of different sizes were observed in both samples in Fig. 3(a)(c). However, the size of agglomerates was larger in the CuZnZr sample, and the particles were more evenly distributed with smaller and fewer agglomerates in the 2Re/CuZnZr sample. The result indicates the inclusion of Re promoted the dispersion of Cu metal and reduced the tendency of metal particles to aggregate during the reduction process. Fig. 3 (b)(d) shows the distribution of Cu and ZnO with Cu (200), Cu (111), ZnO (101), and ZnO (102) crystal planes observed for both samples. The presence of Re was found to promote the distribution of ZnO between the Cu grains through both sets of images. The role of ZnO in the catalyst is mainly to act as a spacer to reduce the aggregation of metal Cu and promote the dispersion of Cu0 during the reduction process of the catalyst [30]. This means that the introduction of Re makes ZnO play the role of spacer better. So, the number of Cu0 aggregates was reduced on the 2Re/CuZnZr sample with a low number and small size of Cu0 aggregates. This finding aligns with the outcomes obtained through XRD analysis. STEM-EDS tests were performed on the catalysts to further investigate the metal distribution states in them. The results are shown in Fig. 4 , where the distribution of Cu and Zn species in the CuZnZr samples overlapped and were in close contact with each other. The overlapping region of Cu and Zn species in the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst was more extensive, which also implied that the interaction between the metal and the carrier (SMSI) was enhanced [31]. This is consistent with the enhanced metal-carrier interactions shown with the previous XRD. In addition, it was observed that the Cu particles in Fig. 4 (a) were dispersed on the ZnO surface in the form of multiple larger agglomerates, while the Cu particles in Fig. 4 (b) were uniformly dispersed on the ZnO surface, which further supports the TEM finding. 3.3 Reductive properties The reducibility of the catalysts was assessed using H2-TPR within the temperature range of 50–800 °C. The deconvolution TPR spectra of the CuZnZr, 2Re/CuZnZr, and 4Re/CuZnZr catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The catalysts with component CuZnZr were generally located between 180 and 300 °C regarding the position of the CuO reduction peaks [32,33], so the H2 consumption peaks located between 170 and 300 °C for all catalysts were the characteristic peaks for the reduction of CuO to Cu. Furthermore, the baseline drift observed in the temperature range of 300 °C to 700 °C can be attributed to the reduction process of trace ZnO [34]. The amount of hydrogen consumed by the reduction of ZnO did not vary with the change of Re loading (Table 3). According to the results on Re2O7 (Fig. S1) and the reported literatures [35,36] the reduction temperature of rhenium oxides is in the range of 300–500 °C. The characteristic peaks for the reduction of Re species were not found in Fig. 5(a). However, according to the results of the actual hydrogen consumption of CuO in Table 3, the hydrogen consumption increases with the increase of Re loading. Thus the reduction of Re species proceeds almost simultaneously with the reduction of CuO, resulting in only one characteristic peak between 170 and 300 °C. Therefore, under the reduction conditions in this paper, the Zn species in the catalyst mainly exist in the form of ZnO, and the Re species exist in the form of Re0. The reduction curve was divided into two Gaussian peaks to investigate the catalyst reduction behavior more intuitively (Fig. 5(b)). Due to the low Re loading, the hydrogen consumption for the reduction of Re species in the catalyst is much lower than that for the reduction of CuO (The ratio of the theoretical hydrogen consumption for the reduction of Re species to that for the reduction of CuO in the 4Re/CuZnZr catalyst is only 7 %), so the peak splitting results in Fig. 5(b) are not the peaks produced by the reduction of Re species. The peak positions and area ratios that resulted from deconvolution are displayed in Table 3. According to reports [37–39] when CuO gets into contact with ZrO2, it undergoes two phases of reduction (CuO-Cu2O-Cu). ZrO2 stabilized the Cu2O intermediates more than ZnO, producing prominent shoulder peaks in the TPR spectra. Peak α was caused by the improved CuO reduction brought on by interaction with ZrO2, which led to the stabilization of Cu2O species at lower reduction temperatures. Peak β was caused mostly by a reduction in body phase CuO species and further reduction of Cu2O species. With increasing Re loading, the proportion of α peak area gradually falls while the proportion of β peak area increases, indicating that Re reduced the interaction between Cu and ZrO2 and expedited the transition of Cu2O to Cu. According to the examination of the overall reduction temperature, the reduction temperature rises as Re loading increases. Since the three groups of catalysts have the same CuO grain size (Table 2), the CuO grain size is not the reason for the increase of reduction temperature. This implies that Re will interact aggressively with the Cu species on the catalyst surface throughout the reduction process after the introduction of the proper Re species into CuZnZr. In the end, this interaction prevents nascent Cu0 from migrating and congregating on the surface of big particles [40], which hinders the reduction of Cu2+ species and raises the reduction temperature. 3.4 Surface basic site and hydrogen dissociation adsorption capacity The investigation of the catalyst's surface alkalinity was conducted by the CO2-TPD method. The CO2-TPD spectra of the catalysts at 50–800 °C are shown in Fig. 6 (a). The curves underwent a process of deconvolution, resulting in their division into three distinct zones [33,37,41]: weak basic sites or OH groups associated with the Cu surface (50–200 °C), the presence of oxygen defects in ZnO or ZnO x species on the Cu surface following reduction may account for the medium-strong basic sites observed in catalysts (200–460 °C), and strong basic sites associated with low-coordinated O2- species (460–800 °C). The CO2-TPD results of 2Re/ZnZr catalyst, 2Re/CuZr catalyst and 2Re/CuZn catalyst with ZnZr catalyst, CuZr catalyst and CuZn catalyst are shown in Fig. S2. The results showed that there was no increase in the characteristic peaks of basic sites on the catalysts before and after loading the Re additives. Therefore, the loading of Re additive does not increase the basic adsorption sites, and the basic site adsorption does not come from Re additive. The peaks showed in the CuZr, ZnZr, and CuZnZr catalysts between 460 and 800 °C, as depicted in Fig. 6(b), could be attributed to the presence of ZrO2. This was owing to the availability of additional CO2 adsorption sites inside the Lewis basic sites of ZrO2 [42]. In addition, the increase in the number of medium-strong basic sites in the CuZnZr catalyst after Zr addition could be attributed to the presence of additional CO2 adsorption sites on the Lewis basic sites present on ZrO2 [41,43]. The medium-strong basic sites of 4Re/CuZnZr were 2.28 times higher than those of CuZnZr (Table 3 ). This may be due to the fact that Re increases the number of medium-strong basic sites by promoting Cu-ZnO interactions or by increasing the number of ZnO x oxygen defects [37]. At the same time, the presence of Re promotes the further dispersion of ZrO2, which leads to the disappearance of the original small number of strongly basic sites in the CuZnZr catalyst. The adsorption of H2 on the surface active sites of hydrogenation catalysts is an important factor affecting the catalytic activity. The H2-TPD results are shown in Fig. 7 . It can be found that all samples exhibit a minor desorption peak within the temperature range of 80–120 °C. This desorption peak can be attributed to the reversible adsorption of hydrogen on the surface of the Cu-ZnO [44,45]. For the deconvolution of the CuZnZr sample curves (100–800 °C), three peaks existed, representing different degrees of relative H2 adsorption [23] (peak between 80 and 120 °C was identified as weak adsorption, peak between 200 and 300 °C was identified as moderate adsorption and peak between 300 and 500 °C was identified as strong adsorption). To further analyze the catalyst CuZnZr, the same tests were performed for CuZn, CuZr, and ZnZr, and the results are shown in Fig. 7(b). In these samples, prominent resolved peaks appeared at 100 °C and 350 °C when CuZn was simultaneously present, indicating that the weak and medium adsorption peaks were generated by the interaction of Cu-ZnO with the adsorption capacity of H2. Strong adsorption peaks were generated near 600–700 °C in all samples with the presence of Zr. Therefore, it was considered that Zr has a more robust adsorption capacity for H2. The adsorbed H2 is not easy to remove from the surface of the metal active site dissociation, and the dissociation temperature is higher. The catalysts after loading Re were analyzed by deconvolution of 2Re/CuZnZr and 4Re/CuZnZr in Fig. 7(a). With the increase in Re loading amount, the proportion of weakly adsorbed peak located at 80–120 °C and strongly adsorbed peak at 300–500 °C decreased in area and the proportion of moderately adsorbed peak located at 200–300 °C increased in area. According to the Fig. 7(c), the main H2 adsorption of Re metal on hydrogen was between 200 and 500 °C. In summary, the introduction of Re additives significantly improved the medium adsorption sites of the catalysts for H2, and promoted the activation and adsorption capacity of H2 under reaction conditions. 3.5 Surface electronic state XPS was used to investigate the surface chemical states of reduced-state catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), Cu2p 1/2 satellite peaks existed in all three catalyst groups between 937 and 947 eV, which was mainly due to partial oxidation of the catalysts during post-reduction transfer and during XPS sampling. The area of the satellite peaks decreased gradually with the Re loading, which may be due to the presence of Re inhibiting the oxidation of Cu species. The deconvolution of the Cu2p 3/2 energy level is 931.6 and 933.4 eV, corresponding to the Cu0 or Cu+ and Cu2 + peaks [29], respectively (Fig. 8(b)). With the increase of Re loading the Cu2 + peak shifts first to the lower binding energy and then to the higher binding energy, proving a charge transfer between Cu and Re. The peak corresponding to Cu0 or Cu+ was shifted to high binding energy, and their proportions increased, indicating that adding Re promoted the shift of Cu2 + to Cu0 or Cu+ during the reduction process. The conclusion aligns with the findings of the H2-TPR analysis. From the Cu LMM Auger analysis (Fig. 8(c)), it was shown that there is a clear peak at a Kinetic Energy of 917 eV, which, together with the Binding Energy of 931.6 eV located at Cu2p 3/2, yields a corrected Auger parameter of about 1848.6 eV, which is a clear indication of the presence of the Cu+ species [46]. Cu+ species is an effective active site for ester group activation [47], and the presence of Cu+ contributes to the activation adsorption of γ-butyrolactone, the intermediate product of maleic anhydride hydrogenation, and facilitates the further hydrogenation of γ-butyrolactone to 1,4-butanediol. 3.6 Evaluation of catalytic performances Generally, Petroleum-based or biobased maleic anhydride (MA) hydrogenation to form 1,4-butanediol (BDO) occurs at the metal active site, and the reaction pathway is shown in Scheme 1 . The CC of MA is first hydrogenated to form succinic anhydride (SA), a process that occurs very readily. SA is then hydrogenated to form γ-butyrolactone (GBL), which is then hydrogenated via ring-opening to form BDO. Tetrahydrofuran (THF) is formed by the dehydration and cyclization of BDO at the acidic site. The by-product butanol (BL) is mainly produced by the continued hydrogenation of BDO. In the MA hydrogenation reaction, there is competition between the three products (GBL, BDO and THF) generated, with low temperature and high pressure favoring the generation of BDO. According to the GC–MS results (Fig. S5), small amounts of dimethyl succinate, propanol, γ-hydroxybutyric acid methyl ester and butyric anhydride were also generated in the reaction. It has been reported that the feedstock of MA and its derivatives hydrogenation will be transesterified with the product BDO to produce polyester by-products [19,21,48–51]. These by-products not only adhered to the catalyst surface and reduced the catalyst activity, but also decreased the carbon balance of the reaction. In particular, when the reaction is carried out with MA or SA as the raw material, the catalyst activity decreases due to the polyester by-products, which leads to the incomplete conversion of MA or SA. The unconverted MA or SA causes further damage to the catalyst, aggravate the accumulation of carbon on the surface of the catalyst and accelerate the rate of deactivation of the catalyst, and ultimately lead to the phenomenon of blockage of the device pipeline. According to the experimental results in Tabs. S1, S3 and S10, when the conversion of MA or SA is less than 90 %, the catalyst activity decreases rapidly until deactivation, and the carbon atom balance decreases. The catalyst activity decreases slowly when the conversion of MA or SA is between 90 % and 97 %. Therefore, when investigating the performance of maleic anhydride or succinic anhydride hydrogenation catalysts, it is necessary to maintain their conversions at a high level to ensure the reproducibility and stability of the experiments. To investigate the role played by Re in the MA hydrogenation reaction, the following comparative experiments were carried out. 2Re/CuZr, 2Re/ZnZr, and 2Re/CuZn catalysts were obtained by loading 2 % Re on CuZr, ZnZr, and CuZn, respectively. The MA hydrogenation reaction was carried out at 190 °C and 6 MPa; the data are shown in Table S1. It was found that the addition of Re enhanced the original catalysts' activity, and the BDO yields on CuZn and 2Re/CuZn remained high, while the BDO yields on the other component catalysts were meager. It has been reported that the Cu-ZnO interface is the main site for the generation of alcohols by ester hydrogenation [19,52–54], and the addition of Re enhances the Cu-ZnO interaction and thus promotes the generation of BDO. Meanwhile, Re loading on the catalyst surface as the promoter will provide a small amount of CO hydrogenation active sites, which enhances all catalyst activities. The addition of the additive Re to the Cu-Zn catalysts also improves the catalyst activity at low temperatures (Table S1). As shown in Fig. S3, although the MA conversion was maintained at 98 % at the beginning of the reaction, the MA conversion continued to decrease over time, with the rate of decrease being lower on the 2Re/CuZn catalyst than on the CuZn catalyst. Combining the results from Table S1 and Fig. S3, Re can improve the low-temperature activity of the CuZn catalyst, but it cannot guarantee the stability of the catalyst. Therefore, Zr additive was introduced on the basis of CuZn and stability tests were carried out. The results are shown in Fig. S4, and the catalyst remained stable after 100 h of operation. In order to obtain higher BDO yields, Re additives were also introduced on top of CuZnZr and stability tests were conducted on 2Re/CuZnZr catalysts for 200 h (Fig. 14). The catalysts remained stable after 200 h of continuous reaction. The following experiments were carried out to further investigate the reason for the improvement of CuZn catalyst stability by the Zr additive. For the CuZn catalyst after 30 h of reaction, the CuZnZr catalyst after 100 h of reaction and the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst after 200 h of reaction were tested by TG-MS under oxygen atmosphere and Cu grain size were calculated before and after the reaction. The TG-MS results (Fig. S6) showed that the CuZn catalyst after 30 h of reaction lost the most weight. According to the mass spectrometry analysis, the gases produced were H2O (Peak α) and CO2 (Peak β), which indicated that the CuZn catalyst was prone to carbon build-up during the reaction process, which might be caused by unreacted MA or polyester by-products produced during the reaction process adhering to the surface of the catalyst resulting in rapid deactivation of the catalyst. On the other hand, the CuZnZr catalyst after 100 h of reaction and the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst after 200 h of reaction showed lower weight loss, indicating that the catalyst had less carbon accumulation and more stable catalyst operation. From the XRD grain size before and after the reaction, it was shown (Table S8) that the copper grains in the CuZn catalyst had the largest growth rate, which was the important reason for the decrease in catalyst activity. In summary, the introduction of Zr additives reduced the carbon build-up on the catalyst surface and slowed down the growth of active Cu metal grains, which significantly improved the stability of the catalysts. The synergistic effect of the Zr additive with the Re additive in the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst resulted in excellent activity at lower reaction temperatures, while the catalyst remained stable after 200 h of reaction (Fig. 14). The reactions were carried out at 200 °C, 190 °C, and 180 °C over CuZnZr, 2Re/CuZnZr, and 4Re/CuZnZr, respectively, and the catalytic performances are shown in Fig. 9 and Table S2. With the decrease in temperature, the selectivity of the three catalysts for BDO showed an increasing trend, which was in line with the thermodynamic law. The conversion of all three groups of catalysts at 200 °C was 100 %, with the highest selectivity of 78 % for BDO on 2Re/CuZnZr. Notably, the selectivity of the catalysts for GBL continued to decrease with the increase of Re loading, and the selectivity of butanol increased more on 4Re/ CuZnZr to 13.7 %. The conversion of MA over the CuZnZr catalyst was 97.6 % at 190 °C, and both 2Re/ CuZnZr and 4Re/ CuZnZr were fully converted. The product selectivity showed the same pattern as at 200 °C, with the 2Re/ CuZnZr catalyst achieving 85 % selectivity for BDO. The conversion of MA over 4Re/ CuZnZr catalyst was 97.7 % at 180 °C, and the conversion on the CuZnZr catalyst was only 85.6 %. The activity of the CuZnZr catalyst decreased more with decreasing temperature. However, after loading Re, the catalysts could still reach the full conversion state at 190 °C, and the activity was much improved. According to the XRD, STEM-EDS, and H2-TPD results, the active metal dispersion can be significantly improved by introducing Re into the CuZnZr catalysts to enhance the intermetallic interactions, and the H2 adsorption and dissociation capacity was improved, too. These improvements are the key to the catalyst activity enhancement. Furthermore, combined with the reaction data, the selectivity of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation intermediate GBL decreases with increasing Re loading, indicating that GBL is further converted. It was also found that moderate Re loading improved the selectivity of BDO, whereas excessive Re led to an increase in butanol selectivity. In order to explore the optimum loading of Re more precisely, the results of x(x = 0.25,1,2,4) Re/CuZnZr catalysed reactions at 180 °C and 190 °C are shown in Table S9. The performance of the catalyst did not change significantly when the loading of Re was lower than 2 %, and the reaction produced more by-products of butanol when the loading of Re reached 4 %. In conclusion, the best catalytic performance was obtained when the loading of Re was 2 %. To further investigate that the introduction of Re promoted the conversion of GBL, the intermediate product of maleic anhydride hydrogenation, and to explore the reaction pathway for the preparation of BDO from MA hydrogenation, experiments were carried out on CuZnZr and 2Re/CuZnZr catalysts, respectively. The experiments were designed to use SA, GBL, BDO, and THF, the intermediate products of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation reaction, as starting materials and reacted on CuZnZr and 2Re/CuZnZr catalysts, respectively, under the same conditions. Butanol (BL), as the deep hydrogenation product of this reaction, could not continue the reaction, and no further hydrogenation experiments were performed here. The distribution of the products was observed. When SA was used as the starting material (Fig. 10 , Table S3), the data results were similar to those of MA hydrogenation because the CC of MA is very quickly to be hydrogenated on CuZnZr catalyst. The carbon balance of the reaction decreased rapidly when the conversion of SA was lower than 90 % as shown in Table S3. The reason for the decrease in carbon balance may be that the unreacted SA or the polyester [55] generated by the dehydration condensation reaction between BDO and the insufficiently reacted SA adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, which led to the accumulation of carbon on the surface of the catalyst and thus led to the rapid deactivation of the catalyst. Therefore, to ensure the stability of the SA hydrogenation reaction, it is also necessary to ensure that the SA is maintained at a high conversion level. As shown in Fig. 11 and Table S4, which shows the reaction data with GBL as the starting feedstock, the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst is more favorable for BDO generation, with 94 % conversion and 88.5 % BDO selectivity at 170 °C. Both catalysts' GBL conversion and BDO selectivity increased with decreasing temperature due to thermodynamic limitations. The higher selectivity of the CuZnZr catalyst for BL in the reaction is presumed to be the further hydrogenation of BDO to produce BL. On the other hand, the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst improves GBL conversion due to Re loading replacing a portion of the Cu active site while limiting the further hydrogenation of BDO to BL, thus improving the selectivity to BDO. As shown in Fig. 12 and Table S5, which shows the reaction data with BDO as the starting material, the conversion of BDO by the CuZnZr catalyst was always a higher than that of the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst. The main product was BL, with the yield of the former almost two times that of the latter, which verified the conjecture that BL was converted from BDO in the maleic anhydride hydrogenation reaction. In addition, the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst gave lower yield of THF than the CuZnZr catalyst. The increase in the number of basic sites, according to CO2-TPD data, may limit the dehydration cyclization of BDO to THF. When the reaction was carried out with THF as the starting feedstock (Fig. 13 and Table S6), the CuZnZr catalyst had a lower conversion and the products were mainly BL. The 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst had a higher conversion than that of CuZnZr, and the products were mainly BDO and BL. In summary, Re additives significantly facilitated the conversion of the MA hydrogenation intermediate GBL to BDO, which was the main reason for increased BDO selectivity. When GBL, THF and BDO were used as raw materials for the experiments the results remained stable with no significant downward trend over the reaction times of 10 and 20 h despite the lower conversion. The MA hydrogenation reaction pathway was also further validated. In the literature, most of the 1,4-butanediols were prepared by hydrogenation using maleic anhydride derivatives as feedstock, and the hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a high-pressure batch reactor using precious metals as the main active components. In the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, succinic anhydride and succinic acid, the use of a high-pressure batch reactor for liquid-phase hydrogenation places higher demands on the stability of the catalyst and the corrosion resistance of the unit due to the acidic nature of the feedstock solution. According to the data in Table 4 for hydrogenation reactions using succinic acid as feedstock, higher STY of BDO in high-pressure batch reactor would require higher precious metal loadings, which would increase the cost of industrial applications. In contrast, catalysts using a combination of non-precious and precious metals require longer reaction times to ensure high feedstock conversion. For better comparison with Ref. [18], the experiments were carried out using DMM and MA as feedstock, respectively. The results show that the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst still has a high STY of BDO at a lower reaction temperature, while the selectivity to BDO reaches 85 %. In conclusion, the direct preparation of BDO from maleic anhydride over the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst can reach 85 % yield, and excellent catalytic performance can still be achieved even when DMM is used as the feedstock for the reaction. Repeatability evaluation tests were performed on the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst (Table S7), followed by stability tests. Combined with the characteristics of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation reaction, the maleic anhydride conversion was maintained at 98 % by increasing the LHSV of maleic anhydride to 0.2 h−1. Catalyst stability tests were conducted under these conditions to check the stability of the catalyst while ensuring the normal operation of the plant. The 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst has good stability over a 200-hour run time (Fig. 14 ). 4 Conclusions The CuZnZr metal oxides were synthesized using the co-precipitation method, followed by loading Re onto CuZnZr by the impregnation process to produce xRe/CuZnZr catalysts. The catalysts prepared in this study were used for the one-step gas-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to 1,4-butanediol over a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. The catalyst 2Re/CuZnZr achieved a complete conversion rate of maleic anhydride while exhibiting a selectivity of 85 % towards 1,4-butanediol. The catalytic performance of the catalyst remained stable for 200 h. Compared with the CuZnZr catalysts, the physical and chemical properties of the 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst were significantly improved with the introduction of Re. Meanwhile, Re acted as a promoter to enhance the catalytic activity by providing additional active sites for CO hydrogenation and promoted the conversion of maleic anhydride hydrogenation intermediates to 1,4-butanediol. This finding can inspire the rational design of efficient and environmentally friendly Cu-based catalysts for maleic anhydride hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Producing 1,4-butanediol with selective hydrogenation of maleic anhydride has significant financial benefits. This work reported a “green” one-step method for preparing 1,4-butanediol from maleic anhydride in a gas-phase fixed bed continuous flow reactor over an efficient 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst for the first time. In this paper, CuZnZr composite metal oxides were synthesized using the co-precipitation technique, followed by impregnation of Re to produce xRe/CuZnZr catalysts. The study aimed to investigate the effects of including Re on the catalyst's structure and performance. The results obtained from the characterization indicate that the presence of Re in the system restricts the growth of Cu0 grains. In addition, the inclusion of Re facilitated the utilization of ZnO as an effective spacer, reducing the size and quantity of Cu species agglomerates and enhancing active metal dispersion. This phenomenon may be attributed to being the primary factor responsible for the observed enhancement in the activity of the maleic anhydride hydrogenation reaction. Meanwhile, Re facilitated the transformation of γ-butyrolactone, an intermediate resulting from the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride into 1,4-butanediol. The 2Re/CuZnZr catalyst exhibited favorable catalytic activity under the conditions of 190 °C and 6 MPa, resulting in the complete conversion of maleic anhydride and a selectivity of 85 % towards 1,4-butanediol. The catalyst showed consistent catalytic performance throughout the 200 h. The finding about the impact of Re promoter on Cu-based catalysts has the potential to yield a highly efficient catalytic system for alcohol generation.
coredata.dc:title: One-step synthesis of 1,4-butanediol from maleic anhydride by gas-phase selective hydrogenation over xRe/CuZnZr catalysts
